newsitem.title: INDIA: Sino-Indian trade grows seven times in 1990-96.
newsitem.headline: Sino-Indian trade grows seven times in 1990-96.

text.p: Bilateral trade between India and China expanded to $1.4 billion in 1996 from $200 million in 1990, the Indian Commerce Ministry said in a statement on Wednesday.

India's exports to China -- mainly oil meals, castor oil, iron ore, marine products, drugs and pharmaceuticals, chemicals, cotton yarn, and primary and semi-finished iron and steel -- increased 80.9 percent in 1996 over the previous year, it said.
India imports coal, chemicals, professional instruments, non-ferrous metals, electronic goods and raw silk from China.
Trade between the world's two most populous nations constitutes only 0.4 percent of China's global trade and just 2.3 percent of India's external trade, it said.
"Compared to the potential, the growth and volume of trade between India and China is still minuscule," the ministry said.
China and India resumed official trade in 1978, 16 years after the two Asian neighbours fought a brief border war.

Formal trade relations were established in 1984 when the two countries signed a trade agreement granting Most Favoured Nation status to each other and agreeing to bilateral trade in freely convertible currencies.
